general.q: What is the diffence between var and let keywords?
general.a: var was introduced with JS. let is introduced with ES6. var has function scope, let has block scope. var gets hoisted but let doesn't.

general.q: What is the difference between == and ===?
general.a: == compares the value not type. But === compares value and type.

general.q: What is the diffence between let and const keywords?
general.a: You can reassign a value to let as much as you want. But you can not reassign a value to const.

general.q: What is the diffence between undefined and null keywords?
general.a: They both represent an empty value. But undefined is type of undefined and null is type of object.

general.q: What is use of Arrow function?
general.a: Normal functions bind 'this' to window's this. But arrow functions don'have their own this so it works well as object methods.

general.q: What is prototypal inheritance?
general.a: Every object has a property called prototype. When you create new objects from an object will automatically inherit the property of its parent. Not by including in itself but instead it uses from it's parent.

general.q: What is the difference between function declaration & function expression?
general.a: Function expressions can not be executed before function declarations. Because function scope stacked before variable scope in runtime of Javascript. And when you pass a function into another function, you need to pass the function expression.

general.q: What is promises and why do we use it?
general.a: When we want to make an async call which has to wait for something to happen. And once it comes back you exit with a callback function. And within that callback function you might need another async call which waits for another callback. So it could become kind of callback hell. To simplify this process we use promises.

general.q: setTimeout() issue?
general.a: setTimeout always gets executed after stack finishes even it has 0 timeout value. Because it's an async operation.

general.q: What is closure and how do we use it?
general.a: When a function returns another function the returning function will hold its environment, basically all variables that it needs. We can see it inside the scopes property of the function.

redux.a: Flux is an application design paradigm used as a replacement for the more traditional MVC pattern. It is not a framework or a library but a new kind of architecture that complements React and the concept of Unidirectional Data Flow. Facebook used this pattern internally when working with React The workflow between dispatcher, stores and views components with distinct inputs and outputs as follows: View -> Action -> Dispatcher -> Store -> View...

Redux is a predictable state container for JavaScript apps based on the Flux design pattern. Redux can be used together with React, or with any other view library. It is tiny (about 2kB) and has no dependencies.

The store holds the application state and supplies the helper methods for accessing the state. We can register to listeners bia subscribe method and dispatch actions from reducers. There is only one Store while using Redux. The store is configured via the createStore function. The single store represents the entire state. Reducers return a state via action.

The reducer is a pure function that takes the previous state and an action, and returns the next state. (prevState, action) => newState. It's called a reducer because it's the type of function you would pass to Array.prototype.reduce(reducer, initialValue). It's very important that the reducer stays pure. You should never mutate its arguments, perform side-effects like API calls and routing transitions, call non-pure functions, e.g. Date.now or Math.random.

redux.q: What is the purpose of the constants in Redux?
redux.a: Constants allow you to easily find all usages of that specific functionality across the project when you use an IDE. It also prevents you from introducing silly bugs caused by typos -- in which case, you will get a ReferenceError immediately. Normally we will save them in a single file (constants.js or actionTypes.js) For example: export const ADD_TODO = 'ADD_TODO'. And you use them in two places: During actions creation in actions file and reducers file.

redux.q: How to use connect from React Redux?
redux.a: Use mapStateToProps(state): It maps the state variables from your store to the props that you specify. You need to return the required object from the state, then you need to wrap component with connect as a HOC. E.g export default connect(mapStateToProps)(App). Or you can map you action dispatchers via mapDispatchToProps(dispatch). You need to import your action first like import {addArticle} from './actions' then mapDispatchToProps = (dispatch) => addArticle: article => dispatch(addArticle(article)). On export; export default connect(null, mapDispatchToProps)(App). If mapStateToProps is absent, we need to pass null at first otherwise we'll get TypeError: dispatch is not a function.

redux.q: What is the difference between React context and React Redux?
redux.a: You can use Context in your application directly and is going to be great for passing down data to deeply nested components which what it was designed for. Whereas Redux is much more powerful and provides a large number of features that the Context Api doesn't provide. Also, React Redux uses context internally but it doesnâ€™t expose this fact in the public API. So you should feel much safer using context via React Redux than directly because if it changes, the burden of updating the code will be on React Redux instead developer responsibility.

Redux middleware is a function that is able to intercept and act accordingly on our Redux actions before they reach the reducer. You can use applyMiddleware func where you can pass each piece of middleware as a new argument. So you just need to pass each piece of middleware you'd like.

Redux Thunk middleware allows you to write action creators that return a function instead of an action. The thunk can be used to delay the dispatch of an action, or to dispatch only if a certain condition is met. The inner function receives the store methods dispatch and getState() as parameters.

redux.q: How to structure Redux top level directories?
redux.a: 1. Components; used for dumb React components unaware of Redux. 2. Containers; used for smart React components connected to Redux. 3. Actions; used for all action creators, where file name corresponds to part of the app. 4. Reducers; used for all reducers, where file name corresponds to state key. 5. Store; used for store initialization.

general.q: What is usage of toBe()?
general.a: Similar to === or Object.is .It's a matcher function / assertion to test a value with exact equality. E.g expect(1).toBe(1) You can negate it with .not.toBe(). Two object may look the same but they're not actually equal. So when we compare same references, toBe is useful.

general.q: What is usage of toEqual()?
general.a: It's a matcher function to test a value with exact equality with different references. This is the main difference from toBe() Like lodash's _.isEqual. E.g var obj = {'a': 1} var other = {'a': 1} _.isEqual(obj, other) -> true, obj === other -> false . We can also use this func with a schema object.

general.q: What is usage of toMatchObject()?
general.a: It's a matcher function to test a value with partial equality. E.g var sub = {a:{b:'c'},d:'e'} var act = {a:{b:'c'}} expect(sub).toMatchObject(act) -> true. But if var sub = {a:{b:'c'},d:'e'} var act = {a:{b:'c'},f:'g'} expect(sub).toMatchObject(act) -> false, and show which property is different. We can also use this func with a schema object.

general.q: What are mocks?
general.a: Mocks are functions that keep track of how they're called and what they're called with.It has a property called mock. It has some information e.g. calls. We can see it bt const = [[[firstArg, secondArg]] = fn.mock.calls . So we can expect these called arguments.

general.q: What is usage of toHaveBeenCalledTimes?
general.a: We can create this function Jest Functions API. We use .toHaveBeenCalledTimes(int) to ensure that a mock function got called exact number of time. E.g let's say you have a drinkEach(drink, Array<flavor>) function that takes a drink function and applies it to array of passed beverages. You might want to check that drink function was called exact number of times. test('drinkEach drinks each drink', () => { const drink = jest.fn(); drinkEach(drink, ['lemon', 'octopus']); expect(drink).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(2); It is also under the alias: .toBeCalledTimes(int)

general.q: What is usage of toHaveBeenCalledWith?
general.a: We can create this function Jest Functions API. We use .toHaveBeenCalledTimes(int) to ensure that a mock function got called exact number of time. It uses toEqual so we can use different references. E.g let's say that you can register a beverage with a register function, and applyToAll(f) should apply the function f to all registered beverages. To make sure this works. test('registration applies correctly to orange La Croix', () => {const beverage = new LaCroix('orange'); register(beverage); const f = jest.fn(); applyToAll(f); expect(f).toHaveBeenCalledWith(beverage); });
